history.content:
Don't cut yourself short - it's easy to believe that everyone is doing everything, but in reality everyone makes sacrifices.

You are taking an above average course load, especially if you are seriously auditing CS70. Some people take less classes, or focus on a few things. And even if you do know people who supposedly do a lot - it's alright, that's awesome for them; all you have to do is continue to work on improving your productivity and skills, and honing your interests.

Find what you love to do or want to do, and prioritize those things. If you feel overloaded right now, consider taking out a class to focus on something else, like research or recruiting or some other hobby.

children.subject:
This is going to be a super long post, and I apologize in advance if it comes off kind of preach-y or overly feels-good. I relate a lot to everything you've said and have felt a lot of these things too! I'm writing about some of the things I've learned over the years and things that have worked for me. Feel free to take what is useful to you and ignore everything else.

First, I want to just discuss some of the points you brought up specifically :) 

> Does anyone ever feel that Berkeley pushes the limits of human productivity?

Yes, and I think that's why a lot of people are here! However, there is a difference between pushing the limit (we should always aim to push ourselves to grow in whatever ways we desire) and unhealthily trying to do too much. --> You can do anything, but not everything! Find the few things you really want to do, and focus wholeheartedly on those things. 

> I'm only take 4 classes(EE16B, Stat 134, Math 53, and a breadth; and auditing CS 70)

This is... a lot!!!! I don't think I've taken 4 full classes in a long time, and I think I've only done three techs a semester about twice in my time here (I'm a senior). Plus you're auditing CS 70! This is hard work!!! Don't feel like you're "not doing much" compared to others. Also, while some people are able to take many classes, do research, extracurriculars, etc. I don't think I've ever found someone who can do everything. We all make sacrifices and have to choose what to spend our time on. Plus, you shouldn't use other people as goalposts, but simply as inspiration. Pick and choose from the people you admire and try to emulate what you like, but you don't have to do everything everyone else is doing.

>  I really enjoy going to live lectures/discussions because I somehow find a beauty in the concepts taught, but if I can achieve that same understanding on a webcast at 1.5 times the speed, am I actually spending my time wisely?

If you enjoy it, I think it's a wise use of your time. Fist, going to lecture/discussion is objectively a productive use. Perhaps it is more effective to watch a lecture at home, but really this only amounts to minutes of your day. Is the joy worth it? Maybe it feels like work, but going to lecture can be a treat as well. Sometimes when I'm overwhelmed by other stressed in life, I go to lecture just to treat it as time that I can be 100% focused on academic topics rather than worry about other things. Maybe it's the same for you too. 

> I've been habitually staying up for over 36 hours at least once every week to do work/study for exams while balancing everything else.

Please sleep :) You know it's good for you and ultimately increases productivity, and is generally very important for your health and sanity. 

Some advice on productivity/time management that has worked for me, and maybe you can try it out:

  • Keep track of how much time you're spending on things. How much time on homework? How much time on extracurriculars? Socializing? Work? etc. Do this for about a week, then look at how you've been spending your time and see where you would like to re-allocate your hours. Sometimes sacrifices have to be made. Sometimes you have to spend less time with friends to do work, or sometimes you have to skip a couple questions on your homework to make time for friends. The second part may sound silly, but sometimes we have to make a decision between these. In the long run, neither is more wrong or correct than the other! It's just up to what we want to do; we have to find the things we actually care about. 
  • Schedule your day-to-day routine rigorously. Not just a to-do list, but block out the times you will spend doing whatever activities on your Google calendar, planner, or whatever. Allocate about 1.5x more time for things than you think it will take. Be realistic about what you can accomplish on any given day. 
  • "Research" your own habits -- what times of day are you most productive? Where are you most productive? Don't be afraid to try something new every day. If it doesn't work, give it one more try, then scratch it off your list of "experiments". Keep on trying until you start converging on what works.
  • Don't be too hard on yourself. I've often let a bad day ruin my entire week, thinking things like "There's no point in trying, since I can't ever keep up with other people". We are always surrounded by amazing people here, but everyone is amazing in their own ways. Some people are just able to work seemingly forever. Some of us aren't; so what? 

+1000 the student answer, to find what you love to do or what you really care about and focus on that. Maybe find ways to merge certain passions together! And sometimes (often!!) those things change from semester to semester, if not week to week. I think it's just about making constant adjustments to get what you want out of life. 

Good luck! 

(And don't forget to sleep!!!)

I walk a very thin and dangerous line. My "pushed" limit is 3 techs + extra curriculars (music, research, small odd jobs) + a social life (not a crazy one, but I hang out with people weekly and know somewhat what's going on in the world). This has been more or less my schedule for the past 4 years, having somewhat questionable time-management skills. Has it been hard? Extremely. How do I do it? One noticeable thing I've done is that I've stopped caring about grades. I sought to really focus on my learning and forget about someone else's opinion about how much they think I know. I'm happy with my usual Bs and Cs; I think it's good enough personally. I think this really takes off a mental load/more work off my plate and I think the sacrifice is worth it. I don't go to lectures or discussions because I'm a slow learner and I often don't find people who teach technical classes good at teaching/giving advice (imo). I often use that time to teach myself or work on assignments. Like everyone else however, I wish I had more time to exercise, eat more, apply for jobs, sleep, have more of a social life, etc. It's really sad what we put ourselves through... 

People often forget that in walking such a thin line uncertainty can come along and knock you down on your feet (getting sick, housing problems, accidents, roommate problems, crime, etc.). I've had a couple of these blows throughout my time here and it's bought me hard to my knees. I hated Berkeley for most of my time here, for the harsh atmosphere it creates and for how nobody holds your hand or seems to care. Yet I've come to appreciate it for making me a stronger individual and providing the landscape for me to grow.

If I could do it over again, I would be more conscious of this line and give myself more wiggle room. There were some things in Berkeley I really didn't need to experience and am probably an example of someone who overdid it, just to seem "above average." Is/Was it worth it? Somewhat. I would tell Freshman year me to enjoy life a little more. "Slow down you crazy child, you so ambitious..." (Billy Joel reference). The push you're feeling on human productivity can only affect you as much as you let it. I wish someone would have told me that earlier.

history.content:
I don't mean for this post to sound like a complaint and I'm sorry if it sounds this way. I just want to hear out comments are out there regarding this topic but:

Does anyone ever feel that Berkeley pushes the limits of human productivity? This might just be me being bad with time management, but I've been habitually staying up for over 36 hours at least once every week to do work/study for exams while balancing everything else. While I personally don't have "much" on my plate, I'm only take 4 classes(EE16B, Stat 134, Math 53, and a breadth; and auditing CS 70) and yet I feel like I still don't have time for everything. My Tuesdays and Thursday schedules have lectures from 8am to 6:30pm while I have 3 discussions and a lecture MWF. My question is, how exactly do people do this on top of research/internships/running decals/exercising/personal leisure or any other extra curricular? At times, I feel like people just don't go to class, yet professors stress the importance of going to lecture and keeping up with the all material that seems like a 20 hour/week task. Time is only so limited and I've thought many a time that sleep is wasting my productivity time, despite knowing that sleep is actually productive and inducive for doing well.

This might just sound like a rant, but to those who have been managing multiple activities on top of the rigor of Berkeley CS/EECS, how do you manage? What's your routine like? Do you even go to your discussions and lectures? How does that affect your understanding of your classes? I really enjoy going to live lectures/discussions because I somehow find a beauty in the concepts taught, but if I can achieve that same understanding on a webcast at 1.5 times the speed, am I actually spending my time wisely? Everyone has the same 168 hours per week, but clearly, some people are much more productive than others despite the similarity in focus, hard work, and lack of distractions. 

@Professors/Instructors who may be looking at this

How you manage to prepare for your lectures on top of your research, conferences, running courses, family life, social life, and health maintenance?
history.subject: Concerns
